admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome of the
            Distribution System Reinforcement Project is rated as
            satisfactory. Key lessons with operational and strategic
            implications for the design of future power sector projects
            are as follows: 1) Provincial Electricity Authority's
            (PEA) bureaucratic and cumbersome procurement process
            resulted in a lengthy procurement cycle. Bank's
            involvement with PEA over the years was ineffective in
            remedying the situation, as most procurement decisions for
            sizable contracts are undertaken at the Board level, over
            which counterparts at PEA management had little control. 2)
            Early approval by the Highway Department of the transmission
            lines design must be sought to avoid bureaucratic delays
            during implementation. Similarly, land acquisition should be
            completed before the start of project implementation, or at
            least, a realistic and concrete time-bound action plan
            should be developed and followed through with close
            monitoring by the Bank and the implementing agency. 3) The
            Bank should be more proactive in enforcing coordination
            among the Project Teams and Project co-financiers. With
            better coordination in place, some mismatch in the
            construction schedules for the transmission lines and
            associated substations could be avoided.
